intro: Triglochin concinna, commonly known as the narrowleaf marsh grass, is a flowering plant native to wetland environments in North America. It is characterized by its slender, grass-like leaves and small, white to pinkish flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in shallow water or moist soils, often found in marshes, pond edges, and along streams. Its rhizomatous growth habit allows it to spread and form dense mats, which help stabilize soil and provide habitat for aquatic life. Triglochin concinna is an important component of wetland ecosystems, contributing to biodiversity and water filtration.
